body_html:
It seems correct to me. A tensor rank refers to the number of dimensions, not the size of its elements. Therefore, a vector has rank 1, a matrix has rank 2, a cube has rank 3, and so on.

This is exemplified in the following sentence A rank two tensor is what we typically think of as a matrix, a rank one tensor is a vector and in the table below extracted from http://tensorflow.org/resources/dims_types.html.

body: It seems correct to me. A tensor rank refers to the number of dimensions, not the size of its elements. Therefore, a vector has rank 1, a matrix has rank 2, a cube has rank 3, and so on. This is exemplified in the following sentence `A rank two tensor is what we typically think of as a matrix, a rank one tensor is a vector` and in the table below extracted from http://tensorflow.org/resources/dims_types.html.
